question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined part in the following sentence.
The entire speech of the revivalist f̲e̲l̲l̲ ̲f̲l̲a̲t̲ ̲w̲i̲t̲h̲ the crowd that was present there.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 25-Sep Shift 1)
option_3: had somewhat of a result on
option_4: had a great impact on
solution:
Correct Answer:
had no effect on

Explanation:

  • The phrase "fell flat with" means "failed to make an impact" or "had no effect" on the audience.

  • The best substitute that retains the original meaning is "had no effect on".

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Mr. Adhil c̲a̲l̲l̲e̲d̲ ̲b̲a̲c̲k̲ ̲b̲u̲t̲ ̲h̲e̲ ̲w̲a̲s̲n̲’̲t̲ ̲a̲b̲l̲e̲ ̲t̲o̲ find the scooter part he needed.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 24-Sep Shift 1)
option_1: called down but he wasn’t able to
option_2: called off but he wasn’t able to
option_3: called around but he wasn’t able to
option_4: called up to but he wasn’t able to
solution:
Correct Answer:called around but he wasn’t able to
Explanation: "Called around" means making multiple phone calls to different places or people to gather information or find something, which fits the context of Mr. Adhil searching for a scooter part.
Other options:

  • Called down: Means to scold or reprimand someone, which is incorrect.

  • Called off: Means to cancel something, which does not fit the sentence.

  • Called up to: Implies phoning someone, but the phrase "called up to" is incorrect in this context.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Raju’s job as a clerk seemed to be b̲a̲d̲ ̲a̲t̲ ̲f̲i̲r̲s̲t̲ ̲b̲e̲c̲a̲u̲s̲e̲ ̲o̲f̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲l̲o̲w̲ ̲s̲a̲l̲a̲r̲y̲,̲ ̲b̲u̲t̲ ̲r̲e̲s̲u̲l̲t̲e̲d̲ ̲i̲n̲ ̲s̲o̲m̲e̲t̲h̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲g̲o̲o̲d̲ ̲h̲a̲p̲p̲e̲n̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲l̲a̲t̲e̲r̲ because it saved him from being unemployed.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 09-Sep Shift 2)
solution:
Correct Answer:a blessing in disguise

Explanation: The phrase "a blessing in disguise" means something that seems bad or unlucky at first but results in something good later. This fits the context of Raju's job, which seemed bad due to the low salary but turned out to be beneficial as it saved him from unemployment.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined word segment in the given sentence.
The wedding was p̲u̲t̲ ̲o̲n̲ until January.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 13-Sep Shift 2)
solution:
Correct Answer: - put off

Explanation:
The phrase "put off" means to delay or postpone something, which fits the context of the sentence about delaying the wedding until January.

Other Options:

  • put up - This typically means to tolerate something or to place something in a position, not related to delaying an event.

  • put in - This generally means to invest time, effort, or resources into something or to submit something (e.g., a request).

  • put down - This means to place something down or to criticize someone, neither of which fit the context of delaying an event.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Charles Darwin is renowned for his book on evolution, ‘On the Origin of Species’, which l̲a̲i̲d̲ ̲d̲o̲w̲n̲ ̲a̲ ̲t̲r̲e̲a̲s̲u̲r̲e̲ ̲o̲f̲ ̲s̲u̲b̲s̲t̲a̲n̲t̲i̲a̲t̲i̲o̲n̲ that evolution occurs, and projected a mechanism, that is, natural selection, for how it does so.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 11-Sep Shift 1)
option_1: laid about a treasure of substantiation
option_2: laid into a treasure of substantiation
option_3: laid out a treasure of substantiation
option_4: laid away a treasure of substantiation
solution:
Correct answer: - laid out a treasure of substantiation

Explanation:

The phrase "laid out" means to explain, present, or describe something systematically or in detail, which fits perfectly in the context of Darwin presenting evidence for evolution.

  • "Laid about" and "laid into" are incorrect because they imply unrelated meanings like moving around or attacking verbally.

  • "Laid away" implies storing or saving, which doesn't align with the context of presenting evidence.

Corrected Sentence:

Charles Darwin is renowned for his book on evolution, ‘On the Origin of Species’, which laid out a treasure of substantiation that evolution occurs, and projected a mechanism, that is, natural selection, for how it does so.

question:
Select the option that can substitute the bracketed word segment correctly and complete the following sentence meaningfully.
You all need to (get into) the books prescribed in your syllabus.

(SSC Selection Post P-12 GL : 21 June Shift-3 GL)
solution:
The correct option to substitute the bracketed word segment is "go through."

So, the sentence would read:
"You all need to go through the books prescribed in your syllabus."

This means to study or review the books carefully.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined words in the given sentence.
My son will c̲a̲r̲r̲y̲ ̲o̲u̲t̲ ̲m̲y̲ ̲b̲u̲s̲i̲n̲e̲s̲s̲ ̲ in my absence.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 28 June Shift-1)
solution:
The most appropriate option to substitute the underlined words "carry out" in the sentence is:

carry on

Explanation:

  • "Carry on" means to continue or manage something, especially in someone else's absence. It fits the context of the sentence, where the son is expected to continue running the business.

Thus, the sentence would be:

My son will carry on my business in my absence.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
It is a fact that the same judgement can often b̲e̲ ̲t̲a̲k̲e̲n̲ ̲b̲y̲ ̲m̲o̲r̲e̲ ̲t̲h̲a̲n̲ one way.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 28 June Shift-1)
option_1: be taken in more than
option_2: be taken for more than
option_3: be taken of more than
option_4: be taken on more than
solution:
The most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment is:

be taken in more than

The correct sentence would be:
"It is a fact that the same judgement can often be taken in more than one way."

This expression means that a judgement or situation can be interpreted or understood in multiple ways.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Doctor wants Tony t̲o̲ ̲c̲u̲t̲ ̲b̲a̲c̲k̲ ̲d̲o̲w̲n̲ junk foods.

(SSC Steno 2024 T-1 : 10 Dec Shift-3)
solution:
Correct Answer: - "to cut back on."

Correct sentence: Doctor wants Tony to cut back on junk foods.

Explanation: -

  • The phrase "cut back on" means to reduce or limit the amount of something, which is the appropriate expression in this context when referring to reducing the intake of junk food.

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select ‘No improvement required’.
It had been a serious offence, but he w̲a̲s̲ ̲l̲e̲t̲ ̲o̲u̲t̲ with a warning.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (30 April))
solution:
Explanation:
The correct improvement is:

was let off

  • The phrase "let off" is a standard phrasal verb meaning to excuse someone from punishment or release them with a warning.

  • The original sentence:
    "It had been a serious offence, but he was let out with a warning."
    is grammatically correct, but "let out" usually refers to releasing someone physically (e.g., from a room or building) and is not idiomatic in the context of being excused from punishment.

  • Corrected sentence:
    "It had been a serious offence, but he was let off with a warning."

Correct Answer: 3

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select ‘No improvement required’.
You o̲u̲g̲h̲t̲ ̲c̲u̲t̲ ̲o̲u̲t̲ your consumption of fats if you want to reduce your weight.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (30 April))
solution:
Solution:

  • The underlined phrase: "ought cut out" is grammatically incorrect.

  • The correct structure is: "ought to + base verb"

  • Here, the base verb is "cut", and we are referring to reducing consumption.

  • Also, the correct phrasal verb is "cut down", not "cut out", when talking about reducing something (like fat consumption).

  • So the correct and improved phrase is: "ought to cut down"

  • Why the other options are incorrect:

  • Option 1: "No improvement required" – incorrect due to improper verb structure.

  • Option 2: "must cut out" – changes the degree of obligation and uses the wrong phrasal verb.

  • Option 3: "ought cut down" – missing "to"; incorrect modal verb structure.

Correct sentence:
"You ought to cut down your consumption of fats if you want to reduce your weight."

question:
The underlined phrase in the given sentence has been used incorrectly. Select the option that can correctly replace the underlined segment.
I am d̲o̲w̲n̲ ̲w̲i̲t̲h̲ her complaints.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (01-July Shift 1))
solution:
The phrase "down with" in this sentence is incorrectly used. The correct replacement is: “fed up with”

"Fed up with": This idiom expresses annoyance, frustration, or exasperation caused
"Down with" can mean being okay or in agreement with something


So the revised sentence would be: "I am fed up with her complaints."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Dhruv’s a̲n̲g̲e̲r̲ ̲b̲l̲a̲z̲e̲d̲ ̲o̲f̲ uncontrollably.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (01-July Shift 3))
solution:
The most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment is: anger blazed up.

Explanation:

The phrase "blazed up" is the correct usage to describe anger flaring or intensifying suddenly and uncontrollably.

Analysis of Options:

  • anger blazed after: Incorrect, as "blazed after" does not convey the intended meaning of sudden intensification.

  • anger blazed up: Correct, as it appropriately describes anger flaring up.

  • anger blazed into: Incorrect, as "blazed into" implies transforming into something else, which is not applicable here.

  • anger blazed onwards: Incorrect, as "blazed onwards" does not fit the context of uncontrollable anger.

Correct Sentence:

Dhruv’s anger blazed up uncontrollably.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Sonam’s cat used to chase the mouse into the kitchen and k̲n̲o̲c̲k̲ ̲t̲h̲r̲o̲u̲g̲h̲ ̲a̲ ̲t̲o̲w̲e̲r̲ ̲o̲f̲ ̲p̲o̲t̲s̲ and pans.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (01-July Shift 4))
option_1: knock out a tower of pots
option_2: knock inside a tower of pots
option_3: knock away a tower of pots
option_4: knock over a tower of pots
solution:
The most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment is "knock over a tower of pots."

Explanation:

  • The phrase "knock over" means to accidentally cause something to fall or be overturned, which fits the context of the cat knocking down a tower of pots and pans.

Here’s why the other options are incorrect:

  • "knock out a tower of pots" – "Knock out" typically refers to hitting something forcefully to make it unconscious or to knock it out of place in a more violent sense, which doesn't match the context here.

  • "knock inside a tower of pots" – "Knock inside" is not a commonly used phrase, and it doesn’t make sense in this context.

  • "knock away a tower of pots" – "Knock away" usually means to remove something by force, which doesn’t fit the idea of toppling over a stack of pots.

Thus, the correct answer is "knock over a tower of pots."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No improvement required’.
I am so glad that I r̲a̲n̲ ̲i̲n̲t̲o̲ you on the way.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (01-July Shift 4))
solution:
The most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment is "ran into."

Explanation:

  • "Ran into" means to meet someone unexpectedly, which fits the context of the sentence, where the speaker is expressing gladness about meeting someone by chance.

Let's review the other options:

  • "Ran away" means to flee or escape, which doesn't make sense in the context of meeting someone.

  • "Ran over" means to hit something or someone with a vehicle, which is not appropriate here.

  • "Ran out of" refers to using up something, such as resources or time, and doesn't fit the context of encountering someone.

Since the correct phrase is "ran into" (although not listed as an option), the sentence is grammatically correct as it is, and the best answer would be:

No improvement required.

question:
Select the option that corrects the following sentence.
All the workers have called of the strike.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (02-July Shift 1))
option_1: All the workers have called at the strike.
option_2: All the workers have called through the strike.
option_3: All the workers have called between the strike.
option_4: All the workers have called off the strike.
solution:
The correct option to fix the sentence is: "All the workers have called off the strike."

Explanation:

  • "Called off" is the correct phrasal verb, meaning to cancel or stop something (in this case, the strike).

Let’s review the other options:

  • "Called at the strike" is incorrect because "call at" is not a phrasal verb used in this context.

  • "Called through the strike" is not a correct expression either.

  • "Called between the strike" is also incorrect, as "between" does not fit the meaning in this context.

Thus, the correct answer is "All the workers have called off the strike."

question:
The underlined phrase in the given sentence has been used incorrectly. Select the option that can correctly replace the underlined segment.
Samita a̲s̲k̲e̲d̲ ̲o̲u̲t̲ a favour of going early today.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (02-July Shift 1))
solution:
The correct option to replace the underlined segment is "asked for."

Explanation:

  • "Asked for" is the correct phrase when requesting something, like a favor, which fits the context of the sentence.

Let’s review the other options:

  • "Asked around" means to inquire with multiple people, which doesn't fit here.

  • "Asked after" means to inquire about someone's well-being, not to request something.

  • "Asked over" typically means to invite someone to one's home, which doesn’t fit the context.

Thus, the correct answer is "asked for."

question:
Select the option that corrects the following sentence.
What are you looking around?

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (02-July Shift 3))
option_1: What are you looking across?
option_2: What are you looking for?
option_3: What are you looking through?
option_4: What are you looking among?
solution:
The correct option is:

"What are you looking for?"

The phrase "looking for" is the correct expression when you are trying to find something. The other options do not convey the intended meaning.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The wizard, while performing an item, accidentally set his own hat on fire and prompted t̲h̲e̲ ̲f̲i̲r̲e̲ ̲a̲l̲a̲r̲m̲ ̲t̲o̲ ̲g̲o̲ ̲o̲n̲.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (02-July Shift 4))
option_1: the fire alarm to go under
option_2: the fire alarm to go away
option_3: the fire alarm to go off
option_4: the fire alarm to go above
solution:
The correct answer is: the fire alarm to go off

Explanation:

The phrase "go off" is commonly used to describe the activation of an alarm, such as a fire alarm. It fits the context perfectly, as the wizard accidentally set his hat on fire, triggering the alarm.

Options Analysis:

  • the fire alarm to go under: Incorrect, as "go under" does not relate to triggering or activating an alarm.

  • the fire alarm to go away: Incorrect, as "go away" implies disappearance and is unrelated to alarm activation.

  • the fire alarm to go off: Correct, as "go off" means to activate, which aligns with the context of the sentence.

  • the fire alarm to go above: Incorrect, as "go above" does not make sense in this context.

Final Answer: the fire alarm to go off

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No improvement required’.
We s̲e̲t̲ ̲u̲p̲ on the journey early in the morning.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (02-July Shift 4))
solution:
The correct answer is: set off

Explanation:

The phrase "set off" means to start a journey, which is appropriate in the given context. The other options do not convey the correct meaning for starting a journey.

Options Analysis:

  • set about: Incorrect, as it means to begin working on something, not to start a journey.

  • No improvement required: Incorrect, as "set up" does not fit in the context of starting a journey.

  • set off: Correct, as it means to start a journey.

  • set in: Incorrect, as it refers to something (like a season or trend) beginning and continuing over a period.

Final Answer: set off

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The new chief is g̲i̲f̲t̲e̲d̲ ̲a̲t̲ the power of eloquence.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (03-July Shift 2))
solution:
The most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the sentence is:

  • gifted with

So, the correct sentence would be:

"The new chief is gifted with the power of eloquence."

Correct answer: gifted with

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined word in the given sentence.
The recent cloudburst completely d̲i̲s̲m̲a̲n̲t̲l̲e̲d̲ the village and its people.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (03-July Shift 2))
solution:
The most appropriate option to substitute the underlined word "dismantled" in the sentence is:

  • took apart

So, the correct sentence would be:

"The recent cloudburst completely took apart the village and its people."

Correct answer: took apart

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Mrs. Lakshmi’s p̲u̲r̲c̲h̲a̲s̲e̲s̲ ̲a̲d̲d̲ ̲a̲r̲o̲u̲n̲d̲ ̲t̲o̲ ₹2,650.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (05-July Shift 1))
solution:
Correct Answer:purchases add up to

Explanation:

The phrasal verb “add up to” means to total or amount to a particular sum, which fits perfectly in the context of money.

Let’s look at the options:

  • add for to – ❌ incorrect and ungrammatical.

  • add up to – ✅ correct; means the total is ₹2,650.

  • add from to – ❌ used for ranges, not totals.

  • add out to – ❌ not a valid phrasal verb.

✅ Therefore, the correct substitution is “add up to”, making the sentence:
“Mrs. Lakshmi’s purchases add up to ₹2,650.”

question:
Select the option that corrects the following sentence.
All tickets of the FIFA World Cup have been sold away.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (05-July Shift 2))
option_1: All tickets of the FIFA World Cup have been sold among.
option_2: All tickets of the FIFA World Cup have been sold out.
option_3: All tickets of the FIFA World Cup have been sold into.
option_4: All tickets of the FIFA World Cup have been sold across.
solution:
Correct Answer:All tickets of the FIFA World Cup have been sold out.

Explanation:

The phrasal verb “sold out” is the correct expression used to indicate that all items (in this case, tickets) have been completely sold.

Let’s evaluate the options:

  • Sold among – ❌ incorrect; "among" is used for distribution, not selling completion.

  • Sold out – ✅ correct phrasal verb meaning no more tickets are available.

  • Sold into – ❌ incorrect usage in this context.

  • Sold across – ❌ grammatically awkward and not idiomatic.

✅ Therefore, “sold out” is the proper and idiomatic correction.

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select ‘No improvement’.
Since my friend was not feeling well, she asked me to c̲o̲m̲e̲ ̲o̲v̲e̲r̲ and take care of her.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (08-July Shift 1))
solution:
Correct Answer:No improvement

Explanation:

The phrase "come over" is a correct and natural phrasal verb used when inviting or asking someone to visit your home or location.

Let’s examine the alternatives:

  • come into – usually refers to entering a place or receiving an inheritance; not suitable here.

  • come through – means to survive or succeed in something, e.g., "She came through the surgery well."

  • come across – means to find something unexpectedly or to seem a certain way.

✅ "Come over" is the right phrase in the context of someone asking another person to visit, especially for support or care. Hence, No improvement is needed.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
As there was no one to l̲o̲o̲k̲ ̲t̲h̲o̲r̲o̲u̲g̲h̲ the orphan, he had to take refuge in the orphanage.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (08-July Shift 4))
solution:
Correct Answer: look after

Explanation:
The sentence is:
"As there was no one to look after the orphan, he had to take refuge in the orphanage."

  • Look after means to take care of someone, which fits the context of caring for an orphan.

  • Look through means to examine or browse something – incorrect here.

  • Look upon means to regard or consider someone in a certain way – not suitable.

  • Look down upon means to consider someone inferior – also incorrect.

Hence, the correct phrasal verb is look after.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution required’.
If you g̲i̲v̲e̲ ̲a̲w̲a̲y̲ smoking, your health will improve.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (10-July Shift 2))
solution:
Correct Answer: give up

Explanation:
The correct phrase for quitting a habit like smoking is "give up."

Let’s evaluate the options:

  • give off – Incorrect; means to emit something, unrelated.

  • give out – Incorrect; means to distribute, unrelated.

  • No substitution required – Incorrect; "give away" is incorrect in this context.

  • give up – ✅ Correct; means to stop or quit.

So, the correct sentence is:
"If you give up smoking, your health will improve."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Peter was the last to know that she had been c̲h̲e̲a̲t̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲o̲f̲ ̲h̲i̲m̲.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (11-July Shift 3))
solution:
Correct Answer: cheating on him

Explanation:
The correct phrase to express being unfaithful in a relationship is "cheating on him."

Let’s evaluate the options:

  • cheating in him – Incorrect; not a standard phrase.

  • cheating on him – ✅ Correct; means being unfaithful to him.

  • cheating up him – Incorrect; not a valid phrase.

  • cheat of him – Incorrect; incorrect preposition and structure.

So, the correct sentence is:
"Peter was the last to know that she had been cheating on him."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Do not l̲a̲t̲e̲r̲ ̲a̲b̲o̲u̲t̲ the street.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (11-July Shift 4))
solution:
Correct Answer: loiter around

Explanation:
The phrase "loiter around" means to stand or wait around without purpose, which fits the intended meaning.

Let’s evaluate the options:

  • litre about – Incorrect; "litre" is a unit of measurement.

  • latter about – Incorrect; "latter" refers to the second of two things.

  • litter about – Incorrect; means to scatter trash.

  • loiter around – ✅ Correct; means to hang around aimlessly.

So, the correct sentence is:
"Do not loiter around the street."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution required’.
I opened the box beneath the table and t̲o̲o̲k̲ ̲o̲f̲ a book, the Materia Medica.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (11-July Shift 4))
solution:
Correct Answer: took out

Explanation:
The phrase "took out" means to remove something from inside a container, which fits the context of taking a book out of the box.

Let’s evaluate the options:

  • took in – Incorrect; means to absorb or understand.

  • took out – ✅ Correct; means to remove.

  • No substitution required – Incorrect; "took of" is wrong in the original sentence.

  • take off – Incorrect; means to remove clothing or to leave quickly.

So, the correct sentence is:
"I opened the box beneath the table and took out a book, the Materia Medica."

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The project f̲e̲l̲l̲ ̲b̲e̲s̲i̲d̲e̲s̲ ̲d̲u̲e̲ ̲t̲o̲ ̲l̲a̲c̲k̲ of funding and support.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.10_08-Oct_Shift-2)
option_1: fell about due to lack
option_2: fell through due to lack
option_3: fell along due to lack
option_4: fell until due to lack
solution:
Correct answer: fell through due to lack

Explanation:

  • The phrasal verb "fell through" means to fail or not be completed successfully.

  • This fits the context of a project failing due to lack of funding and support.

  • Other options:

  • fell about – incorrect phrase

  • fell along – incorrect phrase

  • fell until – incorrect phrase

Correct sentence:
"The project fell through due to lack of funding and support."

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Heba d̲r̲o̲p̲p̲e̲d̲ ̲o̲f̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲c̲l̲u̲b̲ ̲u̲n̲e̲x̲p̲e̲c̲t̲e̲d̲l̲y̲ to say hello and catch up.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.18_15-Oct_Shift-1)
option_1: dropped by the club unexpectedly
option_2: dropped between the club unexpectedly
option_3: dropped besides the club unexpectedly
option_4: dropped for the club unexpectedly
solution:
Correct Answer:dropped by the club unexpectedly

Explanation:

  • The correct phrasal verb is "drop by", which means to visit someone or a place briefly and without prior notice.

  • The sentence refers to Heba making an unplanned visit to the club, so "dropped by the club unexpectedly" fits perfectly.

Let’s eliminate the incorrect options:

  • Dropped between the club – incorrect preposition; doesn’t make sense.

  • Dropped besides the club – "besides" means next to; incorrect context.

  • Dropped for the club – grammatically incorrect and unclear in meaning.

✅ Therefore, the correct replacement is: dropped by the club unexpectedly.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
 Shebna decided to take a̲ ̲b̲r̲e̲a̲k̲ ̲i̲n̲ ̲s̲o̲c̲i̲a̲l̲ ̲m̲e̲d̲i̲a̲, but she found it difficult to disconnect completely.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.33_22-Oct_Shift-1)
option_1: a break from social media
option_2: a break up social media
option_3: a break down social media
option_4: a break of social media
solution:
Answer: a break from social media

Explanation:
The correct phrase to express taking time away is "a break from social media."

  • "Break from" means a pause or rest away from something.

  • "Break up" means to end a relationship, which is incorrect here.

  • "Break down" means to collapse or fail, unrelated here.

  • "Break of" is incorrect usage.

Correct sentence:
"Shebna decided to take a break from social media, but she found it difficult to disconnect completely."

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select 'No improvement'.

The name, Khajuraho, has probably b̲e̲e̲n̲ ̲d̲e̲r̲i̲v̲e̲d̲ ̲f̲r̲o̲m̲ the word ‘Khajoor’, meaning date palm.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.40_28-Oct_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer:No improvement

Explanation:
The sentence:
The name, Khajuraho, has probably been derived from the word ‘Khajoor’, meaning date palm.

This is grammatically correct.

  • "Has been derived from" is the correct passive voice construction in present perfect tense.

  • "Derived from" is the correct phrasal verb, meaning originated from – से निकला हुआ या उत्पन्न हुआ.

Let’s evaluate the options:

  • derives into – ❌ incorrect verb form and wrong preposition

  • derive at – ❌ incorrect phrasal verb

  • be derived into – ❌ grammatically incorrect structure

  • No improvement – ✅ correct as written

So, no improvement is needed. The sentence is already correct.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Do you know the purpose of a fire extinguisher? It helps to p̲u̲t̲ ̲u̲p̲ ̲w̲i̲t̲h̲ an engulfing fire, in case of an emergency.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.41_28-Oct_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer:put out

Explanation:
The phrase "put up with" means to tolerate – सहन करना, which is incorrect in the context of fire.

The correct phrasal verb is "put out", which means to extinguish or stop something from burning – बुझाना।

Let’s examine the options:

  • turn over – to flip or rotate – पलटना → ❌ Not suitable

  • run away with – to escape or elope – भाग जाना → ❌ Irrelevant

  • stand out – to be noticeable – अलग दिखाई देना → ❌ Unrelated

  • put out – to extinguish (a fire) – आग बुझाना → ✅ Correct

Correct sentence:
It helps to put out an engulfing fire, in case of an emergency.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The elusive moon peeked from behind the clouds, i̲l̲l̲u̲m̲i̲n̲a̲t̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲e̲a̲r̲t̲h̲ ̲w̲i̲t̲h̲ its gentle glow.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.41_28-Oct_Shift-3)
option_1: glowing up the earth for
option_3: lighting up the earth with
solution:
Answer:lighting up the earth with

Explanation:
The sentence is describing how the moonlight gently brightens the earth, so we need a phrase that reflects this meaning naturally and clearly.

Let’s analyse the options:

  • glowing up the earth for – grammatically awkward and incorrect usage of "glowing up" → ❌

  • empowering the earth via – doesn’t fit the context; "empowering" is not about light → ❌

  • lighting up the earth with – means illuminating or making the earth bright using something → ✅ Correct

  • encouraging the earth with – illogical in this context → ❌

So, the best substitute for "illuminating the earth with" is "lighting up the earth with" – अपनी कोमल रोशनी से धरती को रोशन करते हुए.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The teacher c̲a̲l̲l̲e̲d̲ ̲u̲p̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲c̲l̲a̲s̲s̲ due to the sudden snowstorm.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.43_29-Oct_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer:called off the class

Explanation:
The phrase "called up the class" is incorrect in this context. The sentence is about cancelling the class because of a snowstorm. The correct phrasal verb is "call off," which means to cancel something – रद्द करना.

Let’s examine the options:

  • called in the class – incorrect; "call in" means to summon or request someone’s presence → ❌

  • called on the class – means to request someone to speak or answer → ❌

  • called out the class – means to shout at or criticise, not cancel → ❌

  • called off the class – means to cancel the class → ✅

Correct sentence:
The teacher called off the class due to the sudden snowstorm.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution required’.
Manisha s̲e̲t̲ ̲a̲p̲a̲r̲t̲ with her friends to explore the countryside.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.45_30-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer:set out

Explanation:
The sentence is:
Manisha set apart with her friends to explore the countryside.

The phrase "set apart" means to keep something or someone separate – अलग करना, which doesn’t fit the context of going on a journey.

The correct phrasal verb here is "set out," which means to begin a journey – यात्रा पर निकलना.

Let’s check the options:

  • set in – usually refers to something beginning (like weather or illness) – ❌

  • set aside – to reserve or save for later – ❌

  • set out – ✅ to begin a journey – सही अर्थ

  • No substitution required – ❌ because “set apart” is incorrect here

Correct sentence:
Manisha set out with her friends to explore the countryside.

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence.
The sports teacher saw a̲c̲r̲o̲s̲s̲ the game and punished the students who were cheating in the game.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.47_30-Oct_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: c) through

Explanation:
The correct phrase is: "The sports teacher saw through the game..."

  • "Saw through" is a phrasal verb meaning to detect the truth or real situation behind something, often when someone is trying to deceive (धोखे को पहचान लेना).

  • Here, it means the teacher understood or detected the cheating happening during the game.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • Across = from one side to the other (आर-पार), not suitable for detecting cheating

  • Underneath and beneath = physically under something (नीचे), not logical here

  • Beside = next to (बगल में), again not relevant

Only "saw through" correctly conveys the intended meaning.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
They l̲o̲o̲k̲e̲d̲ ̲o̲u̲t̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲m̲a̲t̲t̲e̲r̲ ̲a̲n̲d̲ ̲f̲o̲u̲n̲d̲ the root cause of the problem.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.5_01-Oct_Shift-2)
option_1: looked unless the matter and found
option_2: looked into the matter and found
option_3: looked of the matter and found
option_4: looked until the matter and found
solution:
Correct answer:looked into the matter and found

Explanation:

The correct phrasal verb is "look into", which means to investigate or examine something carefully.

Let’s evaluate the options:

  • looked unless the matter and found – ❌ incorrect use of “unless,” and grammatically incorrect

  • looked into the matter and found – ✅ correct phrasal verb and grammatically accurate

  • looked of the matter and found – ❌ incorrect preposition; “looked of” is not a valid phrase

  • looked until the matter and found – ❌ incorrect structure and preposition usage

So, the correct sentence is:
"They looked into the matter and found the root cause of the problem."
